Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by: Rev. Dr. James Green, Jr., Pastor, Universal Baptist Church 742 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11221.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Mealy.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation by  Rev. Dr. James Green, Jr., Pastor, Universal Baptist Church, 742 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11221 was delivered by Council Member Rev. Larry B. Seabrook.

Council Member Mealy moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes
Items.AgendaNote: Motion that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of December 19, 2007 be adopted as printed by Council Member Garodnick.
Items.MinutesNote: Council Member Garodnick moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of December 19, 2007 be adopted as printed.

Items.Title: Messages & Papers from the Mayor

Communication from the Mayor - Submitting the name of Jose Maldonado to the Council for its advice and consent regarding his appointment to the New York City Civil Service Commission, Pursuant to Sections 31 and 813 of the City Charter.
Items.ActionText: This Mayor's Message was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections
Items.MatterName: Jose Maldonado, New York City Civil Service Commission

Items.Title: Communications from City, County & Borough Offices
Hector L. Diaz, a candidate for appointment by the Council as City Clerk and Clerk of the Council pursuant to section 48 of the New York City Charter.
Items.ActionText: This Communication was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections
Items.MatterName: Hector L. Diaz, Appointment by the Council as City Clerk and Clerk of the Council

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By the Chair of the Land Use Committee Council Member Katz:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(c) of the Council and Section 197-d (b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the action of the City Planning Commission on Uniform Land Use Procedure Applications no. C 070523(A), C 070525 ZSM, C 070531(A) ZSM, C 070533 ZSM and C 070534 ZSM shall be subject to Council review.  These items are related Uniform Land Use Procedure Application no. C 070522 ZMM.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning, 616 First Avenue, Manhattan (C070523(A)ZSM)

Items.Title:
By the Chair of the Land Use Committee Council Member Katz:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(c) of the Council and Section 197-d (b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the action of the City Planning Commission on Uniform Land Use Procedure Applications no. C 050237 ZSK shall be subject to Council review.  These items are related Uniform Land Use Procedure Application no. C 050236 ZMK.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: ULURP, 886-894 Dahill Road, Brooklyn (C050236ZMK)

Items.Title: Communication from the Speaker
Discussion of General Orders
Reports of Special Committees
Reports of Standing Committees
Resolution calling upon the United States House of Representatives to pass and the United States Senate to introduce and pass the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act (H.R. 3543).
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the President Pro Tempore  (Council Member Rivera) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: US House of Representatives to pass and the Senate to introduce and pass the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act (H.R. 3543).

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Environmental Protection

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel and the best available technology for reducing the emission of pollutants by diesel fuel-powered ferries owned or operated by the city of New York.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Coupled on GO with the Message of Necessity
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel by diesel fuel-powered ferries owned by, operated by or on behalf of, or leased by the city.

Items.Title: Resolution finding that the enactment of Proposed Int. No. 168-A does not have a significant adverse impact on the environment and is consistent with The State Environmental Quality Review Act.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel by diesel fuel-powered ferries owned by, operated by or on behalf of, or leased by the city.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the United States Congress to pass S. 453, the “Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2007,” introduced by Senator Barack Obama, which prohibits deceptive practices in Federal elections.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following Council Member formally voted against this item: Council Members Vallone, Jr.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass S. 453, the “Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2007."

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Land Use

Resolution approving the decision of the City Planning Commission on ULURP No. C 070247 ZSM (L.U. No. 658), for the grant of a special permit pursuant to Section 74-711 of the Zoning Resolution to modify the use regulations of Section 42-10 to allow residential use (U.G. 2 uses); and Section 42-14D(2) to allow retail use (U.G.6 uses) on portions of the ground floor and cellar of the proposed 9-story building at 325-329 West Broadway where the lot coverage is greater than 3,600 square feet, and to modify the height and setback regulations of Section 43-43 (Minimum Height of Front Wall and required Front Setbacks) and the rear yard regulations of Section 43-313 (For portions of through lots), Borough of Manhattan.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: LU 658 - ULURP, 23-25 Wooster St. and 325-329 W. B'Way, Manhattan (C070247ZSM)

Items.Title: Resolution approving the decision of the City Planning Commission on ULURP No. C 070055 ZSM (L.U. No. 672), for the grant of a special permit pursuant to Section 74-711 of the Zoning Resolution to modify the requirements of Section 42-10 to allow U.G. 2 uses (residential use) on the second through fourth floors and a portion of the fifth floor of an existing 5-story building on property located at 309 Canal Street (Block 231, Lot 5), in an M1-5B District, within the SoHo Cast Iron Historic District, Borough of Manhattan.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: LU 672 - Zoning, 309 Canal Street, Manhattan (C070055ZSM)

Items.Title: General Order Calendar
Commissioner of Deeds
Items.MatterName: Commissioner of Deeds

Items.Title:
Introduction & Reading of Bills
See Attached
Discussion of Resolutions
Resolutons
General Discussion
Extension of Remarks
INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of buildings to provide online access to the rent control or rent stabilization status of an apartment or building.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of buildings to provide online access to the rent control or rent stabilization status of an apartment or building.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring that one of the members of the Board of Standards and Appeals be a financial analyst with professional qualifications and at least ten years’ experience as a financial analyst.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Requiring that one of the members of the Board of Standards and Appeals be a financial analyst with professional qualifications and at least ten years’ experience as a financial analyst.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to consent by an owner of residential real property who receives real property tax benefits to provide access to city agencies.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Consent by an owner of residential real property who receives real property tax benefits to provide access to city agencies.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to denying permits to developers who have repeatedly been found to violate the city’s building codes and zoning laws.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Denying permits to developers who have repeatedly been found to violate the city’s building codes and zoning laws.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal to cooperate with the New York City Department of Buildings to make available on the department’s online database information about the rent regulatory status of a unit or apartment building.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: NYS Division of Housing and Community Renewal to cooperate with the NYC Dept of Buildings to make available on the department’s online database information about the rent regulatory status of a unit or apartment building.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Maltese, S.6331-A, and Assembly Member Brennan, A.8023-B, “AN ACT to amend the general municipal law, in relation to annual statements of disclosure for any city with a population of one million or more”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Annual statements of disclosure for any city with population of million or more.

Items.Title: Resolution finding that the enactment of Proposed Int. No. 104-A does not have a significant adverse impact on the environment and is consistent with The State Environmental Quality Review Act.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MatterName: Recycling, reuse and safe handling of electronic equipment sold in NYC.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on Congress to pass the Child Citizen Protection Act (H.R. 1176) in order to provide discretionary authority to immigration judges to determine that an alien parent of a United States citizen child should not be ordered removed, deported, or excluded from the United States.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Immigration
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass the Immigrant Child Protection Act (H.R. 1176)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the Mayor, the New York City Police Department, and the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to continually reevaluate their protocols and response to field incidents concerning the apprehension of, restraint of, and use of lethal force against emotionally disturbed persons.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Continually reevaluate protocols and response to field incidents concerning the apprehension of, restraint of, and use of lethal force against emotionally disturbed persons.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the New York State Legislature to pass A.4258 and S.5013, which allow for same day registration.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: NYS State Legislature to pass A.4258 and S.5013, which allow for same day registration.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to amend the State election law to permit electronic voter registration.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: State Legislature to amend the State election law to permit electronic voter registration.

Items.Title: Resolution congratulating the New York Giants on their victory in Super Bowl XLII.
Items.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MatterName: Congratulating the New York Giants on their victory in Super Bowl XLII.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision of an annual report on non-governmental funding for New York City parks.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation
Items.MatterName: Requiring the mayor to provide an annual report of funding and/or goods and services by non-governmental entities to NYC parks.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the New York City Police Commissioner not to appoint former Police Officers and other former employees of the New York City Police Department to the Civilian Complaint Review Board unless they have been retired or permanently separated from the Department for at least three years.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Urging the NYC Police Commissioner not to appoint former Police Officers and other former employees of the NYPD to the Civilian Complaint Review Board unless they have been retired or permanently separated from the Dept.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon New York City to adopt the recommendations in the Bronx Borough President Adolfo Carrion, Jr.’s Report, “It’s Not Easy Being Green: How to achieve pro-growth and pro-environmental policies by encouraging the production of green construction materials by the NYC manufacturing industry.”
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MatterName: “It’s Not Easy Being Green: How to achieve pro-growth and pro-environmental policies by encouraging the production of green construction materials by the NYC manufacturing industry.”

Items.Title: Resolution calling for an examination by Mayoral agencies of the ways in which City government is protecting children from the adverse effects of air pollution and how this may be better done.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Examination by Mayoral agencies of the ways in which City government is protecting children from the adverse effects of air pollution and how this may be better done.

Items.Title: Resolution finding that the enactment of Proposed Int. No. 168-A does not have a significant adverse impact on the environment and is consistent with The State Environmental Quality Review Act.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel by diesel fuel-powered ferries owned by, operated by or on behalf of, or leased by the city.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring countdown pedestrian signals at intersections with traffic-control signal photo violation-monitoring systems.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Requiring countdown pedestrian signals at intersections with traffic-control signal photo violation-monitoring systems.

Items.Title: Resolution condemning the “Stop Snitching” trend.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Condemning the “Stop Snitching” trend.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon Metropolitan Transportation Authority to immediately improve service on the G line and to not implement any additional service cuts.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: MTA to immediately improve service on the G line and to not implement any additional service cuts.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State legislature to pass Assembly bill A.9245, which would amend the workers’ compensation law and insurance law in relation to providing benefits for family care.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Amend the workers’ compensation law and insurance law in relation to providing benefits for family care. (A.9245)

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Department of Education to waive the fee associated with fingerprinting for parent volunteers in schools to encourage parent participation in the school system.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Department of Education to waive the fee associated with fingerprinting for parent volunteers in schools to encourage parent participation in the school system.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting obstructions or nuisances in or upon sidewalks, flagging or curbstones, streets and medians of streets and establishing a rebuttable presumption regarding responsibility for the placement of signs constituting such obstructions or nuisances.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting obstructing signs on sidewalks, flagging and curbstone whether or not abutting the offending property.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to electronic pay stubs for city employees.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Electronic pay stubs for city employees.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the State legislature to amend the State Election Law to require local Boards of Election, including the Board of Elections in the City of New York, to mail two separate notifications to all registered voters, one with information about the primary election in their district and a separate mailing informing voters about the general election.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Boards of Election, to mail two separate notifications to all registered voters, one with information about the primary election in their district and a separate mailing informing voters about the general election.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to fences.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Fences

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring community advisory groups, waste containerization, on-site truck queuing, and vehicle cleaning at private transfer stations that handle municipal waste.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MatterName: Requiring community advisory groups, waste containerization, on-site truck queuing, and vehicle cleaning at private transfer stations that handle municipal waste.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to removing restrictions on a taxicab operator’s choice of a credit/debit card processor.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Removing restrictions on a taxicab operator’s choice of a credit/debit card processor.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to pass Assembly bill A.9454 which would establish a Commission on the Infrastructure of New York State to ensure that the infrastructure of the State meets current and future demand and facilitates economic growth, is maintained in a manner that ensures public safety, and is developed or modified in a sustainable manner.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MatterName: Establish a Commission on the Infrastructure of New York State. (A.9454)

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Transportation

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel and the best available technology for reducing the emission of pollutants by diesel fuel-powered ferries owned or operated by the city of New York.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Coupled on GO with the Message of Necessity
Items.MinutesNote: For the vote on this item, please see the Report of the Committee on Environmental Protection for Int No. 168-A printed earlier in these Minutes.
